Reviews.Content: An Historic Treasure Beautiful historic hotel on the main square near the cathedrals and presidential palace. Magnificent architecture and style. The lobby is breathtaking with the ceiling panels and old elevators.The rooms are very well appointed, large and well laid out. One note, the room key must be inserted into the slot to run the lighting in the room. A wonderful energy saving device that US hotels should adopt.Dinner on the rooftop restaurant over looking the main square is a must. The food it good but the view can't be beat.

Reviews.Content: Beautiful lobby, great location, not much else We liked about this hotel:The lobby - it really is spectacular (but see below)The room - comfortable, clean, and quiet at nightThe location - if you are into museums and architecture you won't get betterWe didn't like so much:The service - we had to carry our bags in and out, including up some pretty steep steps. None of the staff were helpful.The food - the restaurant was closed, the cafe pretty awfulThe lobby - you are not allowed to sit in there - the chairs are marked off and you can't use the posh escalators or even walk up the stairs!The internet access - it took a number of turns round the hotel, various cables and unhelpful staff to establish it wasn't working that dayFor us, this hotel had no soul, but fine for a stopover.

Reviews.Content: overall far better than anyone told me four day november weekend in mexico city at gran hotel in the Zocalo. hotel location special//rooftop restuarant very good//lobby just as pretty as guide books report//traffic unbeliveable then comes sunday and cars not allowed in Zocalo ,wow // walk around zocalo and see natve dancers / shaman (witch doctors)doing rituals/aztec temple/and the beat goes on
Reviews.Author: edmne

Reviews.Content: Dreadful noise, surly staff - a concert venue not a hotel While the grand atrium (from which all rooms lead off) was impressive(faded grandure) and the room was perfectly clean and comfortable, we were stunned to find out that the hotel was to host a full-on ballwith live music in the atrium on our last night AND that it would only BEGIN at 10pm, with the music finishing at 3am...Unlike one of the other reviewers on this site - we were never informed that the hotel had such a policy or asked to sign a waiver. In fact we only found out about the ball when we came back to the hotel and discovered tables and a stage being set up.The noise was incredible - with huge speakers blasting around the atrium so that even the bedroom door (on the third floor) reverebrated. Even with ear plus in, I couldn't get any sleep until 4am. It wasn't amusing either for my heavily pregnant wife.The staff at the hotel were totally unsympathetic and quite surly when I complained the next day. Some form of apology would have been nice but it wasn't forthcoming. One just gets the impression that they do this all the time and that the business from hosting all night balls is clearly more important to them than revenues from guests who have paid good money for a room supposedly to sleep in.Take my advice - steer clear. There are plenty of nice hotels in Mexico City, especially in more buzzy parts of town.
Reviews.Author: jasonanddebbie

Reviews.Content: Faded elegance *REALLY NOISY on Saturday night* Upon check-in, we were asked to read and sign a waiver that stated we had been informed that the hotel frequently rents out the beautiful lobby for parties. We were told that our room was far from the noise; however, this was not true. Our room was on the top floor, but that didn't prevent us from hearing the very loud party that went on until 4:00 am because the lobby is open. We saw very few other guests during the time we stayed at the hotel and wondered if the hotel made most of its money from renting out that stupendous lobby. Aside from a noisy Saturday night, our stay was fine. The only other complaint that I have is that the hotel does not seem clean. It is our impression that the cleaning crew merely makes up the bed and replaces the bath towels. Having given our negative feedback, it is only fair to list some positive points. The location is wonderful; you're within walking distance of the National Palace, for example. And the hotel staff is friendly and accommodating. In addition, we were pleasantly surprised to find a business room containing two computers, both with access to the internet, for the hotel guests. The lobby-level restaurant serves a wonderful brunch during the week. And, that lobby is so beautiful that it's listed in tour guides as something to see in the Zocalo. The birds in the enormous wrought-iron cages in the lobby are some of the vestiges of the aging hotel's former glory.I probably would not stay here again.
Reviews.Author: Travelbug5000

Reviews.Content: Beautiful hotel in good location This hotel is located away from the main tourist spot in Mexico city which is the Zona Rosa. It is however fabulously located for the Zocalo, the cathedral and for Templo Mayor in the heart of the Historic Centre. The hotel itself is very imposing in a beautiful building. The inside is based around an enormous foyer with a Tiffany ceiling and Art Deco ironwork. The big foyer is however used for weddings and other parties. We were there over a Saturday evening, and when we arrived we were asked to sign a letter to say that we knew that there would be a noisy wedding there and that we had been informed and waived any right to claim compensation for noise. We appreciated being informed, but not being asked to sign waivers. And it was noisy, but we slept reasonably well with ear plugs. The hotel room was large and luxurious, as was the bathroom. We had a safe and mini bar, AC and all the usual stuff. Service in the hotel was a bit indifferent and they didn't always carry out things that they had promised to do. Our room didn鈥檛 overlook the street, which was just as well as drummers played until late in the square and the traffic was very busy. Not many places to eat nearby, but having said that, we did eat very well. We ate at two of the big nearby hotels which had terraces overlooking the square, which was a fabulous sight in the evening, being full of dancers and music. Our best meal was at the place which is on the top floor of the building next to the Holiday Inn overlooking the square, where they sell Mexican artisan goods. We didn鈥檛 eat dinner in the hotel, although the menu looked good. Breakfast was not included in our room price but there is a 7 / 11 right next door to the hotel door, and a Starbucks opposite and down the road a little.
Reviews.Author: Louise_Parker

Reviews.Content: Horror Night bad service, unfriendly staff, By the check-in we were presented a disclaimer that an event is taking place on this saturday evening and it can get a little bit loud. After asking the unfriendly receptionist about the event, we were told that the event is a wedding reception, that will last until 2 am. She offered a (less noisy!!!) room at the 4th floorThe reception included live music, so it was impossible to sleep at 12pm, and the party will going on 'til 4 am. We insisted at the reception that we want a new hotel. After refusing this, the receptionist offered us after 15 minutes discussion a junior suite. In this room we found it was less noisy, so we considerer to stay.So:-At weekend: Don't stay there!! -When you like the place and its loud, insist on a bigger room = Suite-DON'T SIGN THE DISCLAIMER! -At breakfast check the packed food for expiry date!! ;-)The hotel looks lovely, but still it was the worst hotel experience in our life.
Reviews.Author: roger34

Reviews.Content: College Grads Run Amock We encountered very similar problems as the previous reviewer: Upon arriving in Mexico City very late in the evening , we were told that the hotel atrium had been rented by graduating college students the following night and that the party would be quite loud and would last at least until 4 or 5 am. We, too, were presented with a disclaimer to sign.We were able to flee the night of the noisy event to a very nice hotel two doors down on the Zocalo and were spared paying for the noisy night in question. As we returned from dinner the next evening, we encountered two other refugees from theCiudad's noise checking into our new hotel. The Gran Ciudad is lovely, but the rooms, while nice, are not as architecturally chichi as the decor in the interior atrium. By all means, stop by the Gran Ciudad Hotel, check out the great atrium and the stunning tiffany glass ceiling, but don't stay there. It seems the management finds loud parties too lucrative to turn down. Because the hotel rooms are situated around the central atrium, sound does indeed carry. If you are at the hotel during a party you simply will not sleep until it breaks up.The hotel really should inform visitors BEFORE they check in.
Reviews.Author: luv_big_cities

Reviews.Content: nightmare experience You would be wise to pop in to see the beautiful interior and quickly flee. This hotel is gorgeous, but with the absolute worst service and overall accomodations I have ever experienced. I made my reservation one month in advance, but when I arrived the reservation was not in the system. No problem, I thought, I have the confirmation number and printed proof of my online reservation. The girl at the check out desk was rude and literally shrugged her shoulders. Luckily, the manager stepped in and found us a room. However, he said we'd need to switch rooms the next day. When we went to the new room, it had one tiny double bed. This despite the fact that we were registered as three people. I called to inquire, talking to the same shoulder shrugger as the previous day. She offered nothing, saying the hotel was full. I asked if there was a cot they could roll in. She huffed -- literally -- and said there wasn't enough space in the room. I convinced her that there was and finally she agreed to check on it. So, all seemed decent. Then, as we were leaving in the afternoon, the eye roller stopped us and asked to sign an agreement. The agreement said there was going to be a wedding reception in the hotel and we agreed to the fact that music would be playing from 9-3 a.m. Did we have a choice but to sign? No! It was either agree or leave. At this point we were literally on our way out the door and didn't have it in us to sacrifice a day in the city to find new accomodations. We signed. The party ended at 5 a.m. I got absolutely so sleep, completely lost the next day. The manager offered nothing. Again, the absolute worst hotel experience of my life.
Reviews.Author: KRISTANITZA

Reviews.Author: ArleneChicago

Reviews.Content: A hidden gem We stayed here for 4 nights and loved it. The location is fantastic being virtually on the Zocalo, so it's great for sightseeing during the day. The Centro Historico, amazingly, is really quiet in the evening with a lot of the restaurants closing early. Once we got the taxi situation sorted out (taxi crime is rife in Mexico City so you have to be very careful) we went elsewhere for dinner and drinks and had a great timeThe hotel is lovely - the beautiful Tiffany glass ceiling along with the lovely, large birdcages give the foyer a very opulent look. We had a standard room overlooking a side street - the bedroom and bathroom were very nicely decorated and were of a really good standard - we weren't bothered by street noise. The staff were pleasant and very helpful.The perfect place to stay in Mexico City.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Gran Hotel - Zocalo Mexico City Faded Glory but still clinging on to its landlocked Titanic grandeur. Staff are most helpful, Rooms clean and well looked after, Breakfasts and meals in were of a high standard, but it all shut down very early and there were very few other guests as far as we could tell.Still it was acording to local legend the most expensive hotel in Mexico City, possibly all of Mexico. The peso is good value at the moment so give it a try. Its handy for all the main city centre attractions with most of the big shopping areas close by too.Get a room facing the Zocalo then open the balcony doors and revel in the Rock Concerts or political rallies that seem to be on the square all the time.
Reviews.Author: firconel

Reviews.Content: Wonderful hotel - THE place to stay in Mexico City Excellent location just round the corner of the Zocalo which is the main square in Mexico City.Beautiful hotel - originally a department store - that has been sympathetically renovated in accordance with the original design.A special mention to the lovely doorman / bellhop Constantino who amazingly speaks just about every language on the planet! Only a few words but my wife was gobsmacked when he started nattering away in her native Croatian!Continental breakfast was taken on the ground floor cafe. It included coffee, juice, a pastry, fruit and a choice betweeen waffles or pancakes or French toast.The double rooms are absolutely huge - 20 foot by 20 foot at a guess plus a dressing  wardrobe area plus a generous size bathroom. These rooms don't have a view as such - they face internally. We also stayed in a smaller room (called sencillo locally) which were much cosier. It also had a very large bathroom which included a bath plus a stylish glass shower cubicle. The smaller (sencillo) rooms overlook the side street.Rooms have aircon, tv with a couple of english channels (fox news, cnn), mini bar, desk, bathrobes, safe  internet connection points for your laptop (charged locally).We did not eat at the restaurant. The menu seemed okay but not that extensive.The hotel has a business centre with free Internet access.Rack rate for rooms is around 拢100 per room per night but we paid just 拢64 through Hotel Pronto including tax  continental breakfast - much cheaper than any other websites selling this hotel.If like me you want to avoid staying in huge modern glass skyscrapers, then choose this hotel - it has bags of character. I haven't got a bad word to say about it. However, if you want a quieter location, this hotel is right in the thick of things  you'd probably be advised to stay elsewhere in Mexico City or at least choose the rooms away from hustle  bustle of the Zocalo which had an all-night Easter rock concert during our stay. Those crazy Mexicans!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Art Nouveau elegance Early 20th century elegance (1908) on the southwest corner of the Z贸calo. Comfortable and very convenient. Rooftop restaurant. The impressive lobby is topped by a Tiffany skylight.
Reviews.Author: Acapulqueno

Reviews.Content: Great Hotel My friends and I found ourselves stranded in Mexico City in the middle of the night when our flight was cancelled, and the person at the airport got us a reservation at this hotel. We did not arrive until 2:30 AM. The staff were incredibly helpful and friendly. They got us set up in a nice room, helped us with our luggage and with the phone so that we could call home. The hotel is very beautiful and is in a great part of the city. I would definitely recommend it to anyone.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
